citation.article-title: Classification of some coryneform bacteria in a new genus Aureobacterium

p.s: Description of Aureobacterium barkeri nom rev.; comb. nov.

Good growth on solid media in air: colonies are 1 to 3 mm diam., circular, low convex, entire margin, opaque and moist. A yellow pigment is produced. In young cultures, small irregular rods occur; some cells are arranged at an angle to give V-formations. In older cultures rods become shorter. Rods are Gram-positive, non acid-fast, motile; endospores are not formed. Optimum growth temperature ca. 28°C. Obligately aerobic.
Slow and weak, oxidative acid production from glucose and some other sugars.
Aesculin, starch, hippurate, Tween 20, 40 and 60 hydrolysed.
Pectinolytic; pectin methyl esterase and pectin transeliminase produced.
Cell wall peptidoglycan based upon D-ornithine, type B2β (i.e. [L-Hsr]-D-Glu-Gly-D-Orn; Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
Glycan moiety of peptidoglycan contains glycolyl and acetyl residues.
Non-hydroxylated long-chain fatty acids consist of predominantly anteiso- and iso-methyl branched-chain acids; small amounts of straight-chain acids are anteiso-C15 and anteiso-C17.
Major menaquinones are MK-11 and MK-12.
Polar lipids comprise diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidyylglycerol and diglycosyldiacylglycerol DNA base composition values in the range 68.7 to 74.4 mol% G + C have been reported.
Isolated from a raw domestic sewage (Dias et al., 1962).
